descriptions.content:
Historically speaking, of the nominalizing suffixes, the suffix པ་ occupies an essential place to the extent that it is the basic marker of nominalization in Literary Tibetan. In Standard Spoken Tibetan, however, it has far fewer functions.

In Literary Tibetan, the suffix པ་ sometimes appears in the variant form བ་. But be careful: this modification applies only to verb suffixes, and not to suffixes with other functions such as noun or adjective suffixes. Thus Standard Tibetan says ཁང་པ་ “house” and སྟོང་པ་ “empty,” not *ཁང་བ་ and *སྟོང་བ་.

In Literary Tibetan the variants པ་ and བ་ are used as follows:

  • པ་ is used after the consonants ག་, ད་, ན་, བ་, མ་, ས་, ད་དྲག་, and པ་
  • བ་ is used after vowels and the consonants ང་, འ་, ར་, and ལ་

In the spoken language, this rule is usually not followed, and the form པ་ is used in all contexts. Some speakers do, however, follow the rule. In this case, the /w/ of the suffix /wa/ disappears, and the consonant is then doubled:

  • ནང་བ་ becomes pronounced ནང་ང་
  • ཕུལ་བ་ becomes pronounced ཕུལ་ལ་
  • ཚར་བ་ becomes pronounced ཚར་ར་

The suffix པ་ is associated only with the past tense form of the verb, and refers to a past perfective action.

  • ཞུས་པ་ but not *ཞུ་པ་
  • བཟས་པ་ but not *ཟ་པ་

A nominalized verb may be followed by a demonstrative, an indefinite article, or other determinants such as any substantive.

  • གསུངས་པ་དེ་ཚོ། “Those that [you] mentioned....”
